STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 23, 2024
Mark Kwarciany
Delta/Dickinson/Menominee DHHS
305 LUDINGTON ST,
ESCANABA, MI, 49829-4056
RE: License#: CP210201090
Dear Mr. Kwarciany:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 09/19/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City MI. 49684
231-383-5531
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
One of three foster care files reviewed contained a USP where an FTM was not
held during the service plan period.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers,
and unrelated court ordered caregivers.

Two of three foster care files reviewed documented three PATP’s with late
signatures. Therefore, the signature pages were not uploaded into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
09/26/23 Interim, CAP Approved 11/06/23
0 9/21/22 Renewal, CAP Approved 09/27/22
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that
incident reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents
named under the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of Corrective Action Plans (CAP). The agency was informed
that starting January 1, 2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's will be
reviewed with the agency at three months and six months. The assigned
Consultant for the agency will work with the agency in conducting CAP
reviews. This process for special investigation CAP reviews was implemented
previously.
• Rule 400.12209 (2) (a) Orientation and Training. The agency was informed
that all the training requirements listed under (2) (a) are required yearly for
foster care workers carrying a caseload as well as for supervisors who may
be carrying a caseload
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on 11/06/23 in
response to those violations established during the 09/26/23 Interim inspection.
The agency CAP was successful in preventing a repeat violation of R 400.12413,
Medical and Dental. The CAP did fail to prevent a repeat violation of FOM 722-
08D, Treatment Plans, as the current inspection established a violation of this
policy. There were no other violations established during the 2023 inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators Assessment was reviewed. The assessment was
thorough and addressed the agency's efforts to comply with the Interim 2023 CAP.
Barriers were noted. One barrier was a foster care worker vacancy which created
additional workload for existing foster care staff. Extra travel time was part of the
increased workload workers experienced due to the vacancy. An experienced
foster care supervisor left the agency, which for a period of time increased the
work load of the other existing supervisor. The newly hired supervisor is currently
learning the requirements of her position. Two experienced foster care workers
also left the agency which created an additional burden on existing staff.
Financial Overview
The agency is a local DHHS office, and financial records were not available.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported enjoying working for the agency. They reported that
their respective supervisors are supportive and knowledgeable. Staff reported they
feel they are part of a supportive team, and everyone works together in making the
agency a well functioning program.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern local DHHS building in downtown Escanaba.
The building is well maintained and has sufficient office space. CHRI documents
were observed to be stored securely.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified one safety alert during her visits to the homes.
Safety Alert #1: The safety alert was generated on 07/11/24. The smoke alarm
required a new battery to be operable and was repositioned to meet the requirement.
Resolution: The caseworker observed via zoom a new battery being placed into the
smoke detector and positioned outside of the bedrooms.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
September 20, 2024
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 23, 2024
